quotes.topic_title: Misconceptions: pain/gain vs context/outcome
quotes.text: I think one of the biggest misconceptions around Jobs to Be Done is this notion that it's pain and gain as opposed to context and outcome.
quotes.speaker: Bob Moesta
quotes.context: Reframes JTBD away from simplistic pain/gain thinking toward analyzing the situation (context) and what people are trying to achieve (outcome).

quotes.topic_title: Misconceptions: pain/gain vs context/outcome
quotes.text: But what you realize is that the context makes the irrational rational.
quotes.speaker: Bob Moesta
quotes.context: A mental model for interpreting surprising customer behavior: it becomes understandable once you uncover the surrounding circumstances.

quotes.topic_title: Misconceptions: pain/gain vs context/outcome
quotes.text: So the moment you hear a story, you go, "I can't believe that," nine times out of 10, it's because you don't have the rest of the story.
quotes.speaker: Bob Moesta
quotes.context: Practical interviewing guidance: disbelief is a signal to dig for missing context rather than dismissing the behavior as an outlier.

quotes.topic_title: Misconceptions: pain/gain vs context/outcome
quotes.text: And so that's what we're trying to do is find, where will people change behavior?
quotes.speaker: Bob Moesta
quotes.context: Clarifies the core objective of JTBD work: identify the conditions under which customers will actually switch or adopt something new.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: In our conversation, we get deep into all aspects of the Jobs to Be Done framework. What is it, how to apply it to your product, when it's not a good fit, how to interview customers to get accurate insights into their struggles, plus examples of how Jobs to Be Done works for zero to one products and a ton more.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Highlights a practical roadmap for applying JTBD, including fit assessment and customer interviewing for real insights.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: One of the most effective ways to create a big leap in your career and something that worked really well for me a few years ago is to create a personal board of directors, a trusted peer group where you can discuss challenges you're having, get career advice, and just kind of gut check how you're thinking about your work, your career, and your life.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Actionable career tactic: deliberately build a peer advisory group to pressure-test decisions and accelerate growth.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: With Sidebar, senior leaders are matched with highly vetted, private supportive peer groups to lean on for unbiased opinions, diverse perspectives, and raw feedback.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Offers an operational model for implementing the “personal board of directors” concept via structured peer groups.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: One of the most effective ways to create a big leap in your career and something that worked really well for me a few years ago is to create a personal board of directors, a trusted peer group where you can discuss challenges you're having, get career advice, and just kind of gut check how you're thinking about your work, your career, and your life.
quotes.speaker: Host
quotes.context: Introduces a practical career-growth framework—building a “personal board of directors”—and explains what it’s used for.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: Why spend a decade finding your people when you can meet them at Sidebar today?
quotes.speaker: Host
quotes.context: A counterintuitive reframing that challenges the assumption that strong peer networks must take years to build organically.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: With one API, your team can add over 180 HR, accounting, ATS, ticketing, CRM, file storage and marketing automation integrations into your product.
quotes.speaker: Host
quotes.context: A concrete data point that quantifies the leverage of using a unified API approach for integrations.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: You can get your first integration into production in a matter of days and save countless weeks building custom integrations, letting you get back to building your core product.
quotes.speaker: Host
quotes.context: Actionable product-development advice: reduce integration drag to reclaim engineering time for core product work.

quotes.topic_title: Why JTBD: hiring products for progress
quotes.text: Jobs to Be Done is this whole premise that people hire products, they don't buy them, they hire them to make progress in their life.
quotes.speaker: Bob Moesta
quotes.context: Defines the core JTBD mental model in a memorable, practitioner-friendly way that reframes product demand around progress.

quotes.topic_title: Why JTBD: hiring products for progress
quotes.text: Snickers typically is a case where they missed the last meal, they've got a lot of work to do, they're running out of energy and they want to basically get back to the tasks as fast as possible.
quotes.speaker: Bob Moesta
quotes.context: Shows how the same product category can map to a specific job/context that drives different positioning and design decisions.

quotes.topic_title: Why JTBD: hiring products for progress
quotes.text: And so you start to realize that if they didn't have a Snickers, it competes with a protein drink, it competes with a Red Bull, a coffee.
quotes.speaker: Bob Moesta
quotes.context: Actionable example of identifying the real competitive set by job-to-be-done rather than by product category.

quotes.topic_title: Why JTBD: hiring products for progress
quotes.text: But a Milky Way typically is eaten after an emotional experience, could be positive, could be negative. It's usually eaten alone, and it's taking time to regroup after this emotional thing.
quotes.speaker: Bob Moesta
quotes.context: Illustrates how different “jobs” can exist within nearly identical products, driven by emotional context and desired outcomes.

quotes.topic_title: Why JTBD: hiring products for progress
quotes.text: jobs helps you see the true competitive set from what we call the demand side of the world as opposed to the competitive set from the supply side of the world, which is the technology or the underlying business model by how which we're making it.
quotes.speaker: Bob Moesta
quotes.context: Contrasts demand-side vs supply-side competition as a practical framework for strategy, research, and product decisions.

quotes.topic_title: Demand comes from struggling moments, not products
quotes.text: Most people think they create a product and that creates demand. But the real thing that if you start to study causality is that a struggling moment causes demand.
quotes.speaker: Bob Moesta
quotes.context: Contrarian reframing that demand is driven by customer struggle, not by product creation—useful for discovery and positioning.

quotes.topic_title: Demand comes from struggling moments, not products
quotes.text: And so all of this starts with a struggling moment, not with a product.
quotes.speaker: Bob Moesta
quotes.context: A concise principle practitioners can use to anchor product strategy and research around real-life triggers rather than feature ideas.

quotes.topic_title: Demand comes from struggling moments, not products
quotes.text: And so that's what we mean when we're customer-centric is that we're studying the struggling moments they have and people like Intercom and Basecamp, they look at struggling moments and that becomes their roadmap.
quotes.speaker: Bob Moesta
quotes.context: Actionable methodology: translate observed struggling moments directly into roadmap inputs instead of feature wishlists.

quotes.topic_title: Demand comes from struggling moments, not products
quotes.text: But if I talk about the struggling moments that I'm trying to go after, all of a sudden I realize that the roadmap is now when I get to that struggling moment, there's multiple ways I can solve it.
quotes.speaker: Bob Moesta
quotes.context: A roadmap mental model that preserves flexibility by committing to problems/struggles rather than specific solutions.

quotes.topic_title: Demand comes from struggling moments, not products
quotes.text: So instead of just talking about features, it's typically talking about features for the first 90 to 120 days, but after that we just talk about struggling moments because that's the seed for real innovation and basically where new products come from.
quotes.speaker: Bob Moesta
quotes.context: Practical planning guidance: limit feature-level commitments to the near term and use struggling moments as the longer-term roadmap unit.

quotes.topic_title: Context/outcome vector and “kick-ass half”
quotes.text: But it's not just the pain. See, what we're taught in business school was pain and gain, but the reality is it's the context.
quotes.speaker: Bob Moesta
quotes.context: Reframes customer research away from generic pain/gain toward situational context as the real driver of choice.

quotes.topic_title: Context/outcome vector and “kick-ass half”
quotes.text: And so part of this is it's not just about pain and gain, it's about context and outcomes.
quotes.speaker: Bob Moesta
quotes.context: Introduces a practical lens for product strategy: map the context customers are in and the outcomes they seek.

quotes.topic_title: Context/outcome vector and “kick-ass half”
quotes.text: And so when you frame it that way, it becomes a vector, a vector of progress or a vector of intention of what they're trying to do.
quotes.speaker: Bob Moesta
quotes.context: Offers a mental model (“vector”) for understanding customer behavior as directional progress, not isolated problems.

quotes.topic_title: Context/outcome vector and “kick-ass half”
quotes.text: And the crazy part is that I was always told or taught if I build the best product, it will sell better. And what I've learned is that actually a kick-ass half is better than a half-ass hole, and that's what Jason talks about.
quotes.speaker: Bob Moesta
quotes.context: Challenges the “best product wins” assumption and argues for focused, context-fit solutions over feature completeness.

quotes.topic_title: Context/outcome vector and “kick-ass half”
quotes.text: But the reality is like if you look at QuickBooks, QuickBooks has half the features and double the price.
quotes.speaker: Bob Moesta
quotes.context: Concrete example showing that winning products can succeed with fewer features when they meet customers where they are.

quotes.topic_title: Forces model: push/pull vs anxiety/habit
quotes.text: And so the real heart of the method of Jobs to Be Done is understanding the causation of what pushes people to say, "Today's the day I got to do something different."
quotes.speaker: Bob Moesta
quotes.context: Defines the core JTBD focus as identifying the causal trigger that makes people ready to switch, not just identifying a pain point.

quotes.topic_title: Forces model: push/pull vs anxiety/habit
quotes.text: And what you start to realize, and I call that F4, is if F1 and F2 are not greater than F3 and F4, they're not going to move, they're not going to do anything.
quotes.speaker: Bob Moesta
quotes.context: Summarizes the four-forces switching model as an inequality you can use to diagnose why adoption stalls.

quotes.topic_title: Forces model: push/pull vs anxiety/habit
quotes.text: And most people say, "If I just add more features, create more pull, people will buy." It's not true. More features create actually anxiety, can it do all those things?
quotes.speaker: Bob Moesta
quotes.context: Challenges the common growth tactic of adding features by explaining how it can increase anxiety and reduce conversion.

quotes.topic_title: Forces model: push/pull vs anxiety/habit
quotes.text: So what did I do? I actually raised the price of the condo, included moving in two years of storage as part of the deal with the condo because it's the frictional coefficient and I increased sales over 30%.
quotes.speaker: Bob Moesta
quotes.context: Concrete example showing that reducing friction (even while raising price) can materially increase adoption.

quotes.topic_title: Forces model: push/pull vs anxiety/habit
quotes.text: We don't need to sell them, we need to enable them to buy.
quotes.speaker: Bob Moesta
quotes.context: Actionable reframing for product and sales teams: design experiences that remove barriers to purchase rather than pushing persuasion.

quotes.topic_title: Demand-side sales: align to customer buying stages
quotes.text: Well, it turns out that the buying process literally has different phases in it. There's the first thought, there's something called passive looking where they're problem aware and solution unaware and they have to learn a bunch of things, and then there's active looking where they're both problem and solution aware and they're trying to figure it out and frame a solution, and then there's deciding which is about making trade-offs.
quotes.speaker: Bob Moesta
quotes.context: Defines a practical demand-side buying-stage framework that can be used to tailor messaging and sales motions.

quotes.topic_title: Demand-side sales: align to customer buying stages
quotes.text: No, no, you have a timeline of how you want to sell to them and after the demo you try to close, but what if they're actually in passive looking and want a demo to learn more? It's very different than if I'm trying to close.
quotes.speaker: Bob Moesta
quotes.context: Challenges the default sales assumption that every demo is a closing event, urging teams to align to the buyer’s actual stage.

quotes.topic_title: Demand-side sales: align to customer buying stages
quotes.text: And you'd think that it would make the sales process longer, it actually made the sales process almost half and at 4x basically conversion because now we meet them where they are as opposed to where we want them to be.
quotes.speaker: Bob Moesta
quotes.context: Concrete outcome data showing that stage-aligned demos can shorten cycle time while dramatically improving conversion.

quotes.topic_title: Demand-side sales: align to customer buying stages
quotes.text: Yeah, there's actually, I call them six phases. First thought, passive looking, active looking, deciding, first use, and then ongoing use. How do we build the new habit?
quotes.speaker: Bob Moesta
quotes.context: Extends the model beyond purchase into adoption, emphasizing that “selling” includes habit formation after first use.

quotes.topic_title: Demand-side sales: align to customer buying stages
quotes.text: And so the method itself is not based on traditional research or market research, asking people what it is. It's actually based on criminal and intelligence interrogation about telling me the story about how you decided today's the day I bought a house or today's the day I went back to school.
quotes.speaker: Bob Moesta
quotes.context: Memorable methodology shift: use narrative decision interviews (not preference surveys) to uncover real causal drivers and trade-offs.

quotes.topic_title: JTBD interviewing: story-first, clustering pathways
quotes.text: And so the first thing we do is we try to extract the story from the customer.
quotes.speaker: Bob Moesta
quotes.context: Core JTBD interviewing method: prioritize the customer’s decision story over opinions to uncover real causality.

quotes.topic_title: JTBD interviewing: story-first, clustering pathways
quotes.text: And so when we get the stories though, then the stories are going to get us the pushes, the pulls, the anxieties and the habits, the trade-offs and what we call the hire and fire criteria.
quotes.speaker: Bob Moesta
quotes.context: A concrete checklist of what a good decision story should reveal for product and positioning work.

quotes.topic_title: JTBD interviewing: story-first, clustering pathways
quotes.text: And then what we do is instead of trying to look for themes across all of them, we actually do something, instead of segmenting them, we cluster them, we find the pathways because what you start to realize is it's not one reason why people do it, it's sets of reasons.
quotes.speaker: Bob Moesta
quotes.context: Counter to typical research synthesis: cluster “pathways” (sets of forces) rather than theme-hunting or demographic segmentation.

quotes.topic_title: JTBD interviewing: story-first, clustering pathways
quotes.text: And so when you start to see the patterns and you start to pull it out, you start to realize that most companies or most products are hired to do 3, 4, 5 different jobs and they're in conflict with each other.
quotes.speaker: Bob Moesta
quotes.context: Highlights why one-size-fits-all messaging/features fail: products often serve multiple conflicting jobs that must be separated or managed.

quotes.topic_title: JTBD interviewing: story-first, clustering pathways
quotes.text: Intercom realized that people hired it for four very, very different reasons and then instead of building four different products, they literally took their product and turned off the features that were not relevant to the pathway that people wanted to take.
quotes.speaker: Bob Moesta
quotes.context: Practical example of pathway-based packaging: tailor the same product by disabling irrelevant features rather than building separate products.

quotes.topic_title: Bob’s dyslexia, writing process, and teaching
quotes.text: So if somebody reads it to me, I can actually play it back. So I'll listen to audio.
quotes.speaker: Bob Moesta
quotes.context: A practical workaround: shift from text-first to audio-first to improve comprehension and retention when reading is a bottleneck.

quotes.topic_title: Bob’s dyslexia, writing process, and teaching
quotes.text: my mom taught me to look at the five largest words on the page by circling the longest words on the page. And then I would study those and translate those and then figure out what those five words would have in common.
quotes.speaker: Bob Moesta
quotes.context: A memorable heuristic for extracting meaning fast: use a small set of high-signal words to infer the gist and structure of a passage.

quotes.topic_title: Bob’s dyslexia, writing process, and teaching
quotes.text: It's really simple, I have a company called Scribe Media, and what we do is first thing we do is we look for what struggling moments do people have? We then look at what are the competitive books wrapped around it? I then basically outline what progress looks like. We then take each chapter and define it as a system and what we have to do in each chapter to help them make the progress along the way.
quotes.speaker: Bob Moesta
quotes.context: A repeatable methodology for writing (or product/content design): start from “struggling moments,” map competition, define desired progress, then systematize chapters as steps.

quotes.topic_title: Bob’s dyslexia, writing process, and teaching
quotes.text: And then we just talk and we talk, we have ten two hour sessions, they get recorded, and then somebody basically takes... So if you listen or read any of my books, it sounds like me talking because it is.
quotes.speaker: Bob Moesta
quotes.context: An actionable production process: capture authentic voice via recorded conversations, then convert to text—useful for founders/leaders who think better out loud.

quotes.topic_title: Bob’s dyslexia, writing process, and teaching
quotes.text: because employees actually hire companies more than companies hire employees.
quotes.speaker: Bob Moesta
quotes.context: A contrarian reframing of recruiting/retention: treat job choice as a “hire” decision by employees, shifting focus to their progress and switching triggers.

quotes.topic_title: Jobs-to-be-Done for career moves and switching jobs
quotes.text: And then when you actually unpack the story, luck had nothing to do with it. They were prepped, they were ready, there was pushes, there were pulls, there was anxieties, they were able to do it.
quotes.speaker: Bob Moesta
quotes.context: Reframes “getting lucky” as a diagnosable set of forces (pushes/pulls/anxieties) you can prepare for and act on.

quotes.topic_title: Jobs-to-be-Done for career moves and switching jobs
quotes.text: And so there's frames around basically understanding what progress are you really trying to make now? Is it, do I need balance? Am I not challenged enough?
quotes.speaker: Bob Moesta
quotes.context: Introduces a practical lens—define the “progress” you seek (balance, challenge, etc.) to guide career decisions.

quotes.topic_title: Jobs-to-be-Done for career moves and switching jobs
quotes.text: And so you start to realize that all of these things where we think we have to pay more money, over 50% of the people who got new jobs didn't get more money. It's a lie. It's about progress.
quotes.speaker: Bob Moesta
quotes.context: Counterintuitive data point that challenges the default assumption that job switching is primarily for higher pay.

quotes.topic_title: Jobs-to-be-Done for career moves and switching jobs
quotes.text: We'll say, "Well, why do you need more money?" It's like, "Well, I have larger obligations," or, "I want more money because I want more respect."
quotes.speaker: Bob Moesta
quotes.context: Actionable interviewing tactic: unpack “money” into underlying drivers like obligations or respect/status.

quotes.topic_title: Jobs-to-be-Done for career moves and switching jobs
quotes.text: There's a whole bunch of things, but it's not just money. That's the interesting part.
quotes.speaker: Bob Moesta
quotes.context: Memorable summary that money often acts as a proxy for deeper hiring/firing criteria and progress metrics.

quotes.topic_title: Interview tactics: who to talk to and how many
quotes.text: The moment somebody says yes, there's nothing more to say.
quotes.speaker: Bob Moesta
quotes.context: A counterintuitive interviewing principle: optimize for eliciting corrections and elaboration rather than agreement.

quotes.topic_title: Interview tactics: who to talk to and how many
quotes.text: The second is I only talk to people who have already tried to make the progress, right?
quotes.speaker: Bob Moesta
quotes.context: A practical sampling rule for JTBD interviews: focus on people with real switching/progress attempts to uncover causal drivers.

quotes.topic_title: Interview tactics: who to talk to and how many
quotes.text: And I usually do 10, no more than 12. And I would rather do two rounds of 12 interviews than do 24 interviews.
quotes.speaker: Bob Moesta
quotes.context: Concrete guidance on interview volume and iteration cadence to find repeating patterns efficiently.

quotes.topic_title: Interview tactics: who to talk to and how many
quotes.text: And so the other tip I have is to not have a discussion guide.
quotes.speaker: Bob Moesta
quotes.context: Challenges standard research practice by prioritizing adaptive follow-ups over rigid scripts to reach the most meaningful information.

quotes.topic_title: Interview tactics: who to talk to and how many
quotes.text: And so what happens is, what I say is I use the framework of pushes, pulls, anxieties and habits and say, "What caused them to do this?"
quotes.speaker: Bob Moesta
quotes.context: A repeatable JTBD framework for structuring interviews around causal forces rather than opinions or feature requests.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: Wherever you work, running experiments is increasingly essential, but there are no commercial tools that integrate with a modern growth team stack.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Highlights a practical gap teams face: experimentation is critical, but tooling often doesn’t fit modern growth workflows.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: This leads to wasted time building internal tools or trying to run your own experiments through a clunky marketing tool.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Actionable warning about the hidden cost of poor experimentation infrastructure and the tradeoffs teams commonly make.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: When I was at Airbnb, one of the things that I loved most about working there was our experimentation platform where I was able to slice and dice data by device types, country, user stage.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Concrete example of how robust experimentation enables deeper analysis across meaningful segments.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: Eppo lets you go beyond click through metrics and instead use your north star metrics like activation, retention, subscription and payments.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Encourages a metrics mental model shift from shallow engagement to business- and product-outcome measures.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: When I think about Jobs to Be Done, I've never fully implemented any sort of structured framework, but I find that it's been really useful in my newsletter work and my podcast work, just thinking about what is the job my newsletter is doing for people?
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Shows a lightweight, practitioner-friendly way to apply JTBD without formal process: focus on the “job” your product/content does.

quotes.topic_title: Lightweight JTBD: start with stories and churn
quotes.text: So there's two things. If I have a product, go find 10 people who recently bought your product, but what I want you do is go talk to them, not about the product, but about why they bought the product, what was going on, what were they hoping for, what were they worried about? What did they have to give up? How did they convince somebody else? Just listen to the story. Start with just getting the story.
quotes.speaker: Bob Moesta
quotes.context: A lightweight, immediately actionable JTBD starting point: interview recent buyers for the decision story rather than product feedback.

quotes.topic_title: Lightweight JTBD: start with stories and churn
quotes.text: Because there's three levels of information we have to get or three sources of energy that I talk about. So think about it as there's got to be energy in the system for us to do something. And there's what I call functional energy, which is usually time, space, effort, knowledge, right? There's emotional energy, which is how I feel. I want to feel better, I feel frustrated, I feel overlooked. There's emotional aspects to it. And then there's social aspects, how I want others to perceive me or how others perceive me, "Oh, my boss is going to fire me because he doesn't think I'm doing this fast enough and I feel inadequate." So part of his understanding kind of the emotional, social and functional components that are part of that energy source.
quotes.speaker: Bob Moesta
quotes.context: A clear framework for diagnosing motivation: functional, emotional, and social “energy” driving a purchase or switch.

quotes.topic_title: Lightweight JTBD: start with stories and churn
quotes.text: The second part is if it's an established product and it's been there a while, I'd actually go and talk to people who churned. Because in churn, what's interesting is when somebody leaves your product, they're still making progress.
quotes.speaker: Bob Moesta
quotes.context: Reframes churn interviews as a high-signal way to learn what progress customers are trying to make when they leave.

quotes.topic_title: Lightweight JTBD: start with stories and churn
quotes.text: Nobody wants to change. So that makes this actually the easiest thing to look at is tell me why people change.
quotes.speaker: Bob Moesta
quotes.context: A counterintuitive lens: because change is resisted, switching triggers are especially diagnostic for product and positioning decisions.

quotes.topic_title: Lightweight JTBD: start with stories and churn
quotes.text: But if I listen to football stats, third down in preseason is very different than third down in playoffs, right? And so giving me a stat about how their third down conversion is across the whole season makes no sense to me because the context is different.
quotes.speaker: Bob Moesta
quotes.context: A memorable example illustrating why aggregate metrics can mislead when context shifts—core to JTBD thinking.

quotes.topic_title: Signals of real switching: beyond complaints
quotes.text: So the phrase I have 'Bitchin' ain't switchin'." Just because people bitch about something doesn't mean they're going to do anything about it.
quotes.speaker: Bob Moesta
quotes.context: A contrarian reminder to prioritize observed behavior over complaints when judging whether users will actually switch.

quotes.topic_title: Signals of real switching: beyond complaints
quotes.text: And this is the other part, if you follow your best users, they'll take you up to this world that then actually destroys the lower end of the world of why people are there.
quotes.speaker: Bob Moesta
quotes.context: Warns that optimizing for power users can overcomplicate the product and erode the core value for the broader market.

quotes.topic_title: Signals of real switching: beyond complaints
quotes.text: And so there's these, I call it the layers of language. And the very first layer is called the pablum layer, where people just, "How was your day?" "Oh, it was good," but nobody knows what that means.
quotes.speaker: Bob Moesta
quotes.context: Introduces a practical interviewing framework for peeling back vague statements to reach concrete causality.

quotes.topic_title: Signals of real switching: beyond complaints
quotes.text: And the way I would describe it is it's criminal and intelligence interrogation that feels like therapy because most people don't actually know why they bought because they only think about the time they wrote the check, swiped the card.
quotes.speaker: Bob Moesta
quotes.context: A memorable methodology for conducting deep customer interviews that reconstruct the real decision journey, not just the purchase moment.

quotes.topic_title: Signals of real switching: beyond complaints
quotes.text: But value is not just the outcome. Value also has where you start.
quotes.speaker: Bob Moesta
quotes.context: A simple mental model that reframes value as progress from a starting point, helping teams avoid overbuilding and overshooting needs.

quotes.topic_title: Zero-to-one challenge: JTBD examples and approach
quotes.text: the fact is you need to study the struggling moments and it helps you determine what not to build, right? Too many times we just keep adding more and more things to the product.
quotes.speaker: Bob Moesta
quotes.context: A practical product-development heuristic: use “struggling moments” to decide what to avoid building, not just what to add.

quotes.topic_title: Zero-to-one challenge: JTBD examples and approach
quotes.text: But the reality is, Jobs to Be Done research is hypothesis building research. I don't know, that's part of the point is we really don't know.
quotes.speaker: Bob Moesta
quotes.context: Reframes JTBD as a discovery method for forming hypotheses rather than validating preconceived ones.

quotes.topic_title: Zero-to-one challenge: JTBD examples and approach
quotes.text: I think Drucker said it best, he goes, "What businesses think they're selling is not what customers are buying."
quotes.speaker: Bob Moesta
quotes.context: A memorable reminder to separate internal product narratives from customers’ real purchase motivations.

quotes.topic_title: Zero-to-one challenge: JTBD examples and approach
quotes.text: But the notion is the way that I frame it is, what will people stop using when your product comes out? And that's who you want to go interview.
quotes.speaker: Bob Moesta
quotes.context: A concrete targeting/interviewing framework: identify the “fired” alternative and interview those users.

quotes.topic_title: Zero-to-one challenge: JTBD examples and approach
quotes.text: There are really no new jobs, it's just the fact is we get better at them.
quotes.speaker: Bob Moesta
quotes.context: A counterintuitive lens for zero-to-one: innovation often improves existing jobs rather than creating new ones.
